news_summary: Google Scholar has enhanced its tool to recognize and give extra credit to first and last authors, improving academic attribution.
news_summary_fr: Google Scholar a amélioré son outil afin de reconnaître et d'accorder un crédit supplémentaire aux premiers et derniers auteurs, améliorant ainsi l'attribution académique.
news_summary_es: Google Scholar ha mejorado su herramienta para reconocer y dar crédito adicional al primer y último autor, mejorando así la atribución académica.

articles.title: Google Scholar tool gives extra credit to first and last authors
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 23 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03281-4Researchers welcome the initiative, but say it doesn’t go far enough to capture the nuance of researcher productivity and impact.
articles.content:
Weighted ratings might help to identify the impact of a researcher’s contributions.Credit: Thawatchai Chawong/iStock via Getty

The h-index — a widely used measure of impact based on publications and citation count over time — treats all of an author’s papers equally, irrespective of whether they are a first, last or middle author. A browser extension called GScholarLens now aims to change that for Google Scholar users.

Launched earlier this year for the Google Chrome and Mozilla Firefox browsers, the tool provides a weighted metric, called the Scholar h-index (Sh-index), which accounts for a researcher’s position in author lists.

The tool gives corresponding (or last) authors the highest weighting: 100% of the citations that their paper accumulates contributed to their Sh-index. First authors receive the second-highest weighting, of 90% of the total citations.

Second authors get a 50% weighting. Other co-authors get 25% if there are six or fewer authors, or 10% if there are seven or more authors, according to a preprint published in September1 by the tool’s creators.

The highest weighting is given to the first and last authors because, in most research fields, they are the people who contributed most to the paper, says GScholarLens co-creator Gaurav Sharma, a computational biologist at the Indian Institute of Technology Hyderabad in Kandi. He adds that the weighting given to authorship positions might be tweaked in the future on the basis of user feedback.

The Sh-index was designed to help researchers, institutions and policymakers to create fairer and more-comprehensive evaluation systems that capture the nuance of authorship, says Sharma.

For example, if a researcher is a co-author on a few very highly cited papers and first or last author on several less-cited papers, their h-index will be high, but their Sh-index will be low, which could give a more accurate picture of their work. “Overall, productivity-wise, contributions of such authors are mostly collaborative in nature, where they often support large teams but seldom lead small or big projects,” says Sharma.

A high h-index and low Sh-index could also help to identify individuals who might be engaging in unethical practices, such as gift or paid authorship — in which researchers become authors of papers without actually contributing to the work.

Capturing the nuance

Fair credit for contributions is a major challenge in academic publishing. In a 2022 survey of around 47,000 researchers across Europe, just under 70% said they’d worked on projects for which some authors hadn’t contributed enough to deserve credit.

Alberto Martín-Martín, an information scientist and bibliometrician at the University of Granada in Spain, says that he is sympathetic to the aims of GScholarLens. But he adds that he is not sure that the tool achieves its goal of making Google Scholar data more useful for research evaluation.

Simply assigning different weights to study authors isn’t enough to capture the nuances of their contributions, says Martín-Martín, because authorship positions themselves aren’t perfect representations of contributions. For example, two researchers might perform the same task in different projects, and one could be assigned a second-author position whereas the other becomes one of the co-authors. He also notes that GScholarLens wrongly assumes that corresponding authors are always last in author lists, which is often not the case.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a new browser extension tool, GScholarLens, that improves the evaluation of researchers' contributions by weighting authorship positions in citation metrics. This innovation addresses a significant issue in academic publishing—fair credit allocation—and has broad implications for research assessment, helping institutions and policymakers create fairer evaluation systems. The article provides sufficient detail about the tool's methodology, purpose, and potential impact, making it a meaningful technological advancement with positive real-world benefits for the academic community.
articles.personality_title: New tool improves how researchers’ work is measured by crediting key authors
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Academic research papers often have many authors, but current tools like the h-index count all authors’ contributions equally. This makes it hard to tell who played a bigger role in the work.

**What happened** – A new browser extension called GScholarLens was launched earlier this year for Chrome and Firefox. It changes how Google Scholar calculates a researcher's impact by giving more credit to the first and last authors of a paper. These authors receive 90% and 100% of the paper’s citations, respectively, while others get less depending on their position.

**Impact** – This new measure, called the Scholar h-index or Sh-index, helps show who really led or contributed most to research projects. It can provide a clearer picture of a researcher’s role, unlike traditional methods that treat all authors the same. It may also help spot unfair authorship practices, where people get credit without doing much work.

**What's next step** – The creators plan to improve the tool based on feedback and hope it will help universities and policymakers make fairer decisions about researchers’ work. Experts say more changes might be needed since author order doesn’t always perfectly show contribution.

**One-sentence takeaway** – GScholarLens offers a smarter way to measure researchers’ impact by giving extra credit to those who lead studies, helping make academic evaluations fairer and clearer.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un nouvel outil améliore la mesure du travail des chercheurs en valorisant les auteurs clés
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les articles de recherche ont souvent plusieurs auteurs, mais les outils actuels comme l’indice h comptent toutes les contributions de manière égale. Cela rend difficile de savoir qui a joué un rôle plus important.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une nouvelle extension de navigateur appelée GScholarLens a été lancée cette année pour Chrome et Firefox. Elle modifie la façon dont Google Scholar calcule l’impact d’un chercheur en donnant plus de crédit aux premiers et derniers auteurs d’un article. Ces auteurs reçoivent respectivement 90 % et 100 % des citations de l’article, tandis que les autres reçoivent moins selon leur position.

**Impact** – Cette nouvelle mesure, appelée indice h du chercheur ou Sh-indice, aide à montrer qui a vraiment dirigé ou le plus contribué aux projets de recherche. Elle donne une image plus claire du rôle d’un chercheur, contrairement aux méthodes traditionnelles qui traitent tous les auteurs de la même manière. Cela peut aussi aider à repérer des pratiques d’attribution injustes, où des personnes sont créditées sans avoir fait beaucoup de travail.

**Prochaine étape** – Les créateurs prévoient d’améliorer l’outil selon les retours des utilisateurs et espèrent qu’il aidera les universités et les décideurs à prendre des décisions plus justes sur le travail des chercheurs. Des experts disent que d’autres changements pourraient être nécessaires car l’ordre des auteurs ne reflète pas toujours parfaitement la contribution.

**Phrase clé** – GScholarLens propose une meilleure façon de mesurer l’impact des chercheurs en valorisant ceux qui dirigent les études, rendant les évaluations académiques plus justes et claires.
articles.personality_title_es: Nueva herramienta mejora la medición del trabajo de los investigadores al dar crédito a autores clave
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los artículos de investigación suelen tener muchos autores, pero las herramientas actuales como el índice h cuentan todas las contribuciones por igual. Esto dificulta saber quién tuvo un papel más importante.

**Qué pasó** – Una nueva extensión de navegador llamada GScholarLens se lanzó este año para Chrome y Firefox. Cambia cómo Google Scholar calcula el impacto de un investigador dando más crédito a los primeros y últimos autores de un artículo. Estos autores reciben el 90 % y 100 % de las citas del artículo, respectivamente, mientras que otros reciben menos según su posición.

**Impacto** – Esta nueva medida, llamada índice h del investigador o Sh-índice, ayuda a mostrar quién realmente dirigió o contribuyó más en los proyectos de investigación. Ofrece una imagen más clara del papel de un investigador, a diferencia de los métodos tradicionales que tratan a todos los autores igual. También puede ayudar a detectar prácticas injustas de autoría, donde personas reciben crédito sin hacer mucho trabajo.

**Próximo paso** – Los creadores planean mejorar la herramienta con base en comentarios y esperan que ayude a universidades y responsables a tomar decisiones más justas sobre el trabajo de los investigadores. Expertos dicen que podrían ser necesarios más cambios porque el orden de los autores no siempre refleja perfectamente la contribución.

**Frase clave** – GScholarLens ofrece una forma más inteligente de medir el impacto de los investigadores al dar crédito extra a quienes lideran los estudios, ayudando a hacer las evaluaciones académicas más justas y claras.
